turns.transcript: This is great. It, thank you, it’s, so much.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: What?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Nothing. I love it.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: No. Something’s going on. What’s wrong with it? I remember you saying how great it would be to have a first edition.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: It’s true, I did. I did say that. When we were at the used bookstore together and I saw the first edition and I bought it.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, my God, I am the worst.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: No, no, it’s okay. It’s really thoughtful.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: No, it’s not. I mean, what’s thoughtful is everything you do. Here, you know what? Look at this. Look, here’s the, the plane ticket you bought me when I was too poor to go home for the holidays. And the rose you left on my windshield just because. Here’s the, the thank-you letter you wrote me after the first time I slept with you. All 11 pages of it.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I can’t believe you saved all this stuff.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Of course I did. It’s you.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Come here.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Is that a pregnancy test?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, yeah, just the first one. I didn’t save them all.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Yeah, see, if you just change the story to the destruction of our galaxy, then a super massive black hole could work.

turns.speaker: Claire
turns.transcript: This is great. Thank you so much. I just got to figure out a way for everyone to die that isn’t too scary for children.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: And that’s how Mommy and Daddy met.

turns.speaker: Claire
turns.transcript: Hey, did you ever tell Emily about us?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I will.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Bernie, I’m home. You have fun today?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Yes, and I have a surprise for you.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Please be Cinderella. Please be Cinderella.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Well, hello, Prince Charming.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Milady.

turns.speaker: phone)
turns.transcript: Yes. Okay. I, I understand. Of course, yes. I’ll call you tomorrow. Bye.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: So I found this fencing school in Burbank that has a Jedi class. And if you’re cool being the only adults there, they said they are.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Dude, my parents just split up.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: What?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Uh, that was my dad on the phone. He moved out.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Oh, my God, I, I’m sorry. I mean, if you’re not up to it, we don’t have to go out, we can just hang here.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: No, it’s fine. It’s not that big a deal. As long as they’re happy, I’m happy. And when I get to see them for the holidays, I’ll get to celebrate Diwali twice, one at each house. That’s double the Diwali.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: You sure you’re okay?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I’m okay.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: You don’t look okay.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: How can I be okay? I come from a broken home.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Hey. What’re you working on?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Remember when I said if you went through with your surgery, there was a one-in-700,000 chance of dying?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yeah?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, I’ve been crunching the numbers, and so far, I’ve gotten your probability of death all the way to a sphincter-tightening one in 300.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Great timing. My check sphincter light just went on.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Leonard, what if you have an allergic reaction to the surgeon’s latex gloves?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I’m not allergic to latex.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, then why don’t you wear the rubber gloves I bought for you to do the dishes?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: For the same reason I don’t wear the apron or the hair net.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Fine. What about epilepsy?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I don’t have epilepsy, either.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You don’t, but the surgeon might, hmm? And your carotid artery is just one shaky scalpel away from becoming the dancing fountain at Disneyland.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Sheldon, do you realize that driving is riskier than surgery?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I do. I have the drive to the hospital right here. That is if you make it to the car without falling down the stairs. And don’t expect me to carry you, I do that enough in life.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Buddy, I, I get that you’re worried about me and I, I appreciate that, but I’m not going to die.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You don’t know that.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Well, I do know that it won’t be from an asteroid strike.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You know who else said that? Every cocky T. Rex currently swimming around in the gas tank of your car.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: If there was an asteroid strike, wouldn’t you die, too?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I don’t know, I’m smart and scrappy, I think I’d find a way.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Tell you what, the surgery’s not for a week, I’ll think about it.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Thank you. And while you’re thinking about it, if you have the surgery in Nicaragua during monsoon season, I can practically guarantee your death.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Close your eyes. Put out your hand. I got you something special.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Come on, Howard. I’m not falling for that again.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: No, here.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Oh, Howie. A little star, it’s beautiful. Put it on me.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Okay, but I’m going to have to get it back from you so I can take it to the International Space Station. That way, when I come home, you will have a star that was actually in space.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Oh, my God.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Take that, every guy who’s ever bought you anything.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: This is the most amazing gift I’ve ever gotten.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Really? Well, if you like it that much, then close your eyes and put out your hand.

turns.speaker: (off)
turns.transcript: ‘m going to the supermarket to buy snacks for your trip. Do you want me to get those little boxes of Froot Loops you like?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: No! When I eat Froot Loops, the other astronauts make fun of me!

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Howard, I don’t want to wait until you’re back to get married.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: What?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I want to be married to you before you get in that rocket.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: But I’m leaving in two days.

turns.speaker: (off)
turns.transcript: What about Apple Jacks?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I don’t need to take cereal.

turns.speaker: (off)
turns.transcript: What kind of breakfast do you think they’re going to give you in Russia?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: They invented blintzes. I’ll be fine.

turns.speaker: (off)
turns.transcript: They invented the lightbulb in New Jersey. It doesn’t mean they hand them out to you when you go.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: We’ll have a quick little ceremony with just our friends, and we’ll still have the big reception with everyone when you get back.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Wow. Okay. Let’s get married.

turns.speaker: (off)
turns.transcript: You know what, I’ll buy you All-Bran in case you get stopped up in outer space.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: How was your shower?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: It was good, good. Just out of curiosity, what time do you usually go to bed?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Oh, I’m up all night. I’m like a possum. Boy, you were not liked in high school, were you?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Not really. Is that my yearbook?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Mm-hmm. Dear Leonard, you’re really good at science. Maybe one day you’ll come up with a cure for being a dork.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Well, it wasn’t spray-painting a lightning bolt on my briefcase, I can tell you that.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: If it makes you feel any better, the only person who signed my yearbook was my mother.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Aw.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Dear Amy, self-respect and a hymen are better than friends and fun. Love, Mom.

turns.speaker: (entering)
turns.transcript: Well, you can add Jerry’s Junction to the list of train stores Sheldon Cooper will never set foot in again.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Rough night, Casey Jones?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You don’t know the half of it. It was billed as a lively give-and-take on the merits of model train sizes. But it was actually a set-up to intimidate weak-minded spineless rubes into buying H-O starter sets.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: What’s in the bag?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I don’t want to talk about it. But it’s not a spine,I’ll tell you that.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Well, I had a delightful evening, Leonard. We should do this again sometime.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Ah, sure. That’d be nice.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Glad to hear it. I need someone to accompany me to the wedding of Dr. Moranelli and Dr. Gustufson this Friday. They’re kind of the Brad and Angelina of the primatology department.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Wouldn’t you rather bring Sheldon?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: I would, but the last wedding we went to was a disaster. He behaved like a child the entire time.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Not my fault. You said there’d be other scientists there my age.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Doesn’t matter. You’re out, he’s in. No date to the prom, two dates to a wedding. Hmm, how times change.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Ha-ha, you have to go to a wedding.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Hey.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Hey.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Hello.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Hi.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: How was your day?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, not good. Still couldn’t get in to see Dr. Gallo.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: A doctor? Well, I hope you’re not contagious. I’ve got a weekend in the telescope room I’ve been excited about for almost three minutes.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I’m not sick. It’s for work. There’s this doctor who refuses to see any sales reps. I’ve been trying to get in for months.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Well, did you try wearing the shirt I said was inappropriate for work?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Well, the doctor’s a woman, but yes, because you never know.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: What kind of doctor is she?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Um, a psychiatrist. Why?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Well, what if you make an appointment as a patient? Then you’ll get to talk to her.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah, they already know I’m a pharmaceutical sales rep.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Oh. What if Leonard made an appointment and tried to lay some groundwork for you?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: That’s interesting.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I’m not gonna make a fake appointment with a psychiatrist. What would I say is wrong with me?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Low self-esteem.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Social anxiety.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Sexual insecurity.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: None of that is true.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Uh, denial. See, sweetie, the list goes on and on.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: That’s just crazy. How would my going in there even help you?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I don’t know. You could talk to her, and maybe if it comes up, you could ask if she’s heard about the drug.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: What if I get caught?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Fear of failure.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Lack of confidence.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Kind of a wuss.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Fine, I’ll do it. But not because of them, because I love you.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Thank you.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Pushover.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Spineless.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Still hasn’t bought milk even though I told him two days ago.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Hello, home wrecker.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: What did I do?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You gave Leonard somewhere to go. Thanks to you, Amy’s out buying his and hers bath towels. Like I’d ever dry myself with something that has a possessive pronoun on it.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay. Listen, the truth is I don’t want him living with me.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Great. Kick him out. Break his heart. Everybody wins.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: No, I don’t want to break his heart. I love him. This is just happening too fast.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You think this is fast? It’s just a matter of time before I see Amy’s leg stubble in my shower.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah, and I’ve seen those legs. You might want to get some Drano.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Hold on. If you don’t want to live with Leonard, why don’t you just tell him?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Well, you know how he is. He’s sensitive and emotional.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: That’s because he drinks too much soy milk.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Well, I don’t know what else we can do but tell them the truth.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I suppose there’s no choice but to face the crying, angry accusations and the high-pitched wails of despair.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah. And who knows how Amy will react.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: In the last two hours, 162 women have read our profiles. How many of them have sent us messages?

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Combined?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Yes.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Zero.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Dude, this is, this is brutal.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: I don’t think I’ve ever felt so rejected. And I had a rescue dog who ran back to the pound.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: This is the worst. If we’re gonna get shot down, we might as well just go to a bar and do it old school.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: And make them look us in the eye.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Yeah, anything is better than this.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Hey, I was thinking, if you want to do a couples costume, we could paint ourselves green and be Hulk and She-Hulk. Or we could paint ourselves blue and go as Nightcrawler and Mystique.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Is there any scenario where we’re not in full body paint?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yeah, if you want us to look like losers.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Hey, um, are you sure the guys are okay with me coming?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yeah, of course, why?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: This is just something you usually do together, and if I’m screwing it up, I don’t have to go.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, why? Do you not want to go?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Why? Do you not want me to go?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: No, I want you to go.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, good, ’cause that’s what I want, too.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: (Knock, knock, knock) Raj. (Knock, knock, knock) Raj. (Knock, knock, knock) Raj.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I’m busy.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Doing what? (Performs finger trick again) All right, you’ve made your point.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: What do you want, Sheldon?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I looked over the board and it turns out you were right.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: So you were wrong.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I didn’t say that.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: That’s the only logical inference.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Nevertheless, I didn’t say it. Anyway, I would like you to come back and work for me.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: For you or with you?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: In this context for me could mean with me.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: All right, but I have some conditions.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I reject them all.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I’ll take the job. See you Monday.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Wait, you have to drive me home.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: How did you get here?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I walked.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: So walk home.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I can’t. There’s a big dog outside. On the way home, we can start thinking about methods of optimizing the detector for 500 GEV particles.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: All right. (As they walk down the corridor, Eye of the Tiger starts playing again.)

turns.speaker: Leslie
turns.transcript: You’re improving.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Thank you. It helps when I get to practice with a real woman.

turns.speaker: Leslie
turns.transcript: Hey, listen. Saturday my sister’s getting married. I.. I want you to come with me. It’s black tie.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Yeah, gee, I’d really rather not.

turns.speaker: Leslie
turns.transcript: Why not?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: When I go to weddings, it’s to scam on chunky bridesmaids. I don’t know what I would do with a date.

turns.speaker: Leslie
turns.transcript: Oh, all right. I understand.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Thanks.

turns.speaker: Leslie
turns.transcript: Hey, I’m really sorry about that Geneva trip.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: What about it?

turns.speaker: Leslie
turns.transcript: Oh, didn’t you hear? I had to reduce the number of people going, and you didn’t make the cut.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: When did that happen?

turns.speaker: Leslie
turns.transcript: About 12 seconds ago.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Well, hold on. Are you saying if I don’t go to the wedding, I can’t go to Geneva?

turns.speaker: Leslie
turns.transcript: Actually, I’m trying not to say it.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Okay, I’m sorry, but that makes me a little uncomfortable.

turns.speaker: Leslie
turns.transcript: How so?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Because it’s like you’re controlling me with new equipment and research trips.

turns.speaker: Leslie
turns.transcript: Well, if I weren’t controlling you with new equipment and research trips, then I’d be uncomfortable.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: How so?

turns.speaker: Leslie
turns.transcript: ‘Cause then we’d be in, like, a real relationship with feelings and all that crap.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: So, bottom line, I’m just a bought-and-paid-for sex toy.

turns.speaker: Leslie
turns.transcript: No. No, not at all. You’re also arm candy. So? What do you think?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Hey, Ma, you got to rent me a tux!

turns.speaker: (voice)
turns.transcript: Right now? What kind of sex are you having up there?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: He showed up in the middle of the night with his bongos. I foolishly thought it was some sort of musical booty call.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Poor guy. He must have been exhausted. Sheldon like to sleep while Leonard play the bongo!

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: That was kind of uncalled for.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: No, it was called for.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: What’s going on?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: All right, Sheldon, this craziness has gone on long enough. Please come home so I can cut your hair.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Penny, you’re not trained. You’re not licensed. Most importantly, you don’t have access to my haircut records.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: All right, honey, look, we’ve known each other for a long time now, right? I’ve taken you to Disneyland, I kicked a bully in the nuts for you, I sing you Soft Kitty when you’re sick, you’ve even saw me naked once.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I’m sorry, duh, what?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: It was a long story. Anyway, Sheldon, I promise I know what I’m doing. Please let me cut your hair.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Amy, what do you think?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: There’s not a hair on my body I wouldn’t let this woman trim.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Fine, let’s go. Thank you for letting me sleep on your couch.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: There’s only so many times a woman can say how about the bed?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: What’s this about Sheldon seeing you naked?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, relax. It was just her bottom and her breasts.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Look at you, putting on a brave face.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: There’s nothing to be brave about. Everything’s fine.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Really? I don’t know how much you know about primate behaviour, but Sheldon’s assistant was clearly courting Leonard. Were she a mandrill, she would have bent over and displayed her brightly coloured hindquarters like a big red welcome mat. By the way, you try that at the junior prom, you get kicked out.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, maybe she was flirting with him, but who cares? Look, I don’t even know where my relationship is with Leonard is right now.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: So says your prefrontal cortex. But meanwhile, the limbic system of your brain is calculating that if another woman is attracted to Leonard, it must be because he’s desirable.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Well, of course he’s desirable. I mean, he’s great. He’s smart, he’s sweet, and, ooh, in the bedroom, whew, let me tell you, he really tries.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: So it does bother you.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Fine, it bothers me a little. No. You know what? This is stupid. It doesn’t bother me. Okay, it bothers me. But only because she wouldn’t stop laughing. Leonard is not that funny.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: And there you have it, prefrontal cortex reasoning versus limbic lust. If this were a boxing match, they might call it the thrilla adjacent to the amygdala. If you were a brain scientist, you would be busting a gut right now.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: No, Dr. Feynman. If I solve it for you, you’ll never learn.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: So, were you turned on even a little bit?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: It was like being hit on by Rat Pack Pee-wee Herman.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I’m sorry, is that a yes?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: No.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Amy, I didn’t want it to come to this, but you have left me no choice but to employ the most passionate, seductive dance known to man. The flamenco.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: For God’s sake, you’re ridiculous.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You guys are aroused, right?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: That was a close one.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: How you feeling?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Good. Little claustrophobic.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Let’s set up the equipment. It’ll help take your mind off of it.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Miners often sang mining songs to keep their spirits up.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Do you know any mining songs?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Just the hits. (Singing) Where it’s dark as a dungeon, and it’s damp as the dew.

turns.speaker: Rajj
turns.transcript: That’s pretty.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Where the dangers are double, and the pleasures are few. Where the rain never falls and the sun never shines, yes, it’s dark as a dungeon way down in the mine.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: It’s a little more bleak than I thought.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, I pray when I’m dead and the ages shall roll, that my body will blacken and turn into coal.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Getting kind of grim.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Then I’ll look from the door of my heavenly home, and pity the miner that mines my poor bones.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Okay. How ’bout a little Miley Cyrus next?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Who’s he?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Huh. That is so strange. Human Resources wants to talk to me tomorrow. (To his dog) Could you stop licking your ass for two minutes? I have a problem here.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Hey, Ames.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Yeah. Hey, Ames, nothing. I was all set to move in with Sheldon, and now I hear I can’t ’cause you don’t want to live with Leonard.

turns.transcript: What?

turns.transcript: I thought we were talking about the other thing.

turns.transcript: You’re a coward.

turns.speaker: Penny

turns.transcript: Um…

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Do you want to catch up on some Walking Dead?

turns.transcript: ‘Kay.

turns.transcript: Have you seen the one where Lori dies?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: No.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Or maybe she doesn’t. Let’s find out.

turns.transcript: Philadelphia.

turns.transcript: Get one yourself.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I think we need to start entertaining the possibility that the Shamy could go on for years.

turns.transcript: Well, if that’s the case, Penny will have to get satellite TV and maybe once a week run a vacuum through this place.

turns.transcript: I did.

turns.speaker: Penny

turns.transcript: I tried, but (Penny starts rubbing her foot with a pumice stone) he made a fairly well-reasoned argument.

turns.transcript: You’re not doing that right.

turns.transcript: What?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Gimme.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: No.

turns.transcript: Trust me.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: No!

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I do this for my mom all the time. See? With the grain.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Wow, that is better.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: And someday, when you have varicose veins, I’ll show you how to massage them.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I think you’re gonna be really happy with this security camera. The optics are great, it’s got infrared technology, and there’s even a backup battery when the power goes out.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Whatever. I can see my little princess while I’m at work, right?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Why can’t you just watch porn like a regular guy? I need your laptop so I can configure the software.

turns.transcript: Wait, hold on. This is weird.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: What?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I was Googling that girl I’ve been dating, and I found her blog.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Cool. Anything juicy?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: She said she recently went on a date with a guy named Roger? And he’s Indian? And he’s an astrophysicist, too?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: You know what’s going on, don’t you?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Yes, Mummy was right. American girls are sexually voracious devils.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I can’t believe I have to explain this. People change names on blogs to protect their privacy. Roger is Raj.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Oh. I always thought, if I had a white name, it would be Gavin.

turns.transcript: Keep reading. What does it say?

turns.speaker: Raj

turns.transcript: I am.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Oh, man. I, what an honour to meet you. I’m, I’m such a fan of Tesla and SpaceX. All your companies. Howard Wolowitz, Caltech.

turns.speaker: Elon
turns.transcript: Nice to meet you, Howard. Feels great to come down here and help the less fortunate, huh?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Oh, yeah. Nothing better than helping people. Which is something I realized when I was viewing Earth from the deck of the International Space Station, where I spent two months as a payload specialist, a job I was qualified for because I’m an MIT-trained engineer.

turns.speaker: Elon
turns.transcript: And I thought I ladled the gravy on thick.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Sorry. It’s just, you’re you, you know? And I really want you to adopt me.

turns.speaker: Elon

turns.transcript: Oh. I made my wife come down, too.

turns.speaker: Elon
turns.transcript: You think you might ever get back out to space?

turns.transcript: Is that a job offer? ‘Cause I really want to go to Mars. Assuming I can bring my wife. She hardly takes up any room. She’s basically a carry-on.

turns.speaker: Elon

turns.speaker: Howard

turns.transcript: Sold.

turns.transcript: Yeah, Amy told me what happened. Look, just apologize. It’ll warm her twaddle.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It’s a Band-Aid at best. See, the core problem is that Amy and Wil do not like each other. Which is baffling because they’re both crazy about me. And I like them, which indicates they’re bright and interesting and/or were on Star Trek.

turns.transcript: I drink tea all the time. I think I know what I’m doing.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Far be it from me to criticize a man with a full pubis. Look, Sheldon, your problem is not Wil Wheaton, okay? Your problem is the way you treated Amy.

turns.speaker: Sheldon

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Sorry.

turns.transcript: On the other hand, that low-down polecat done wronged my woman.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Welcome to Long Island, Tex.

turns.speaker: Sheldon

turns.transcript: Yeah, that she is. Here you go.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I’m so not talking to you. I’m talking to him.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Hey, I’ve got a girlfriend now.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Oh please. My sister’s much hotter than your girlfriend and you know it.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Let’s just agree they’re both hot.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Dude, that’s my sister you’re talking about.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Okay, forget who’s hotter. The first time Priya came to LA, Leonard and I made a pact out of respect to our friendship, and to you, that neither of us would hit on her.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Did you pinky swear?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Yes.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Okay then.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Cobbler. I’m still laughing.

scene: Penny’s apartment. (Montage with scenes in the apartment and Leonard’s bedroom)

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: All right, hurry up and close the door so they can’t hear us. Would you stop pouting? So, you picked my name. Get over it.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yes, and do you know what the odds are I’d pick your name?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: No.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It’s not hard, one in five. Now you know why I’m pouting.

turns.speaker: walkie-talkie)
turns.transcript: All right, teams. Get ready to open your first puzzle. Go. Do you see what I did? The first puzzle is a puzzle. Oh, my God, how adorable is that? I wish I had a friend like me.

turns.transcript: Yeah, well, take them apart and start with the edges. And stop wasting time.

turns.transcript: Wow, you’re really good at puzzles.

turns.transcript: I did them all the time as a kid. As my mom used to say, when you’re doing a puzzle, it’s like having a thousand friends. She was full of fun lies like that.

turns.transcript: If it makes you feel any better, my mom’s just full of pound cake.

turns.transcript: I’m sorry you got stuck with me. I bet you wanted to be with Bernadette.

turns.transcript: Have you ever played a game with Bernadette?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: No.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Have you ever gone into a steel cage with a wolverine?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Faster, faster, faster! Do you not know that word? It means more fast!

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Stop yelling at me.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Hey, you’ll know when I’m yelling at you.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Ooh, ooh, it’s the comic book store. All right, come on, that’s where we have to go.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: But we haven’t finished the puzzle.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: But, it, it doesn’t matter. We know the answer, come on.

turns.speaker: Sheldon

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, it’s not gonna say that.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, I hope you’re wrong. I really want to go to the train store.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: It’s the comic book store. Let’s go.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Come on, numb nuts, it’s the comic book store.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: It’s the comic book store, it’s the comic book store, it’s the comic book store.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It’s the comic book store.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: The interface is pretty simple. You put your horizontal X coordinate here, vertical Y coordinate here. When you’re happy with those, you press this button.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Got it.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Leonard, you’ll never guess who I just found online. Hey!

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Nice shot.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Eh, his giant head did most of the work.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Very mature. You’re lucky I’m out of silly string. As I was saying, Leonard, you’ll never guess who I just found online. Professor Proton.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You’re kidding. He’s still alive?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yes.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Who’s Professor Proton?

turns.transcript: He was the host of this great… Hey!

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yes! Sorry, tell me about Professor Proton.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Professor Proton hosted my favourite science show when I was a child. I never missed an episode. He demonstrated scientific principles using everyday objects.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: It was pretty cool.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Aw, so cute when you use the word cool wrong. Like when kids say pasghetti.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, dear lord, Leonard, look. He’s still available for parties and events. We should hire him.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Hire him to do what?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, whatever we want. Hang out, do experiments, make him take 12 pictures with us so we can make a calendar.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: It would be pretty awesome to hang out with him. I just used awesome wrong, didn’t I?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, I’m e-mailing him right now.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Do you remember his old theme song?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Of course I do.

turns.speaker: Together
turns.transcript: Grab your goggles, put your lab coat on, here he comes, Professor Proton.

scene: The lobby. Penny finds a woman studying the lift.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: It’s out of order.

turns.speaker: Woman
turns.transcript: Yes, I can read the sign, I’m just pondering the implications.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I think it implies that the elevator doesn’t work.

turns.speaker: Woman
turns.transcript: Again, I can read the sign. But the sign and the tape are covered with a layer of dust, which indicates that the elevator has been non-functional for a significant amount of time. Which suggests either a remarkable passivity among the, I assume, 24 to 36 residents of this building based on the number of mailboxes and given typical urban population density or a shared delusion of functionality.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: You must be Leonard’s mother.

turns.speaker: Mother
turns.transcript: Oh, I don’t know if I must be, but yes.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Uh, I’m Penny. I’m his neighbour.

turns.speaker: Mother
turns.transcript: Oh, Dr. Beverley Hofstadter.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, nice to meet you.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Oh, you’re a hand shaker. Interesting.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Uh, why don’t you come with me. I’ll walk you to the apartment.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Oh, all right. Would you like to exchange pleasantries on the way?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah, sure, I guess.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: All right, you start.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay. You know, I’ve always been curious. What was Leonard like when he was little?

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Oh, I think you mean young. He’s always been little.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Right, okay. What was he like when he was young?

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: You’ll have to be more specific.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, um, okay, like, five or six. Five.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Oh, well, at that age he was well enmeshed in what Freud would call the phallic stage of psychosexual development. An outmoded theory, of course, but the boy did spend most of his waking hours with a tight grasp on his penis.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah, Leonard mentioned you were a psychiatrist.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Well, that is one of my degrees. My primary field is neuroscience.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, well, I’m an actress.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Why?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: What do you mean why?

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Well, there are studies that suggest that many who go into the performing arts suffer from an external locus of identity.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah, I don’t know what that means.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Well, it means you value yourself only as others value you, which is often the result of unmet childhood emotional needs.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, well, I had a wonderful childhood.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Tell me about it.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I know my dad wanted a boy. I just, I tried being good at sports, but I hated getting dirty!

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: And then, I’m assuming, you entered adolescence.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Uh-huh, he called me Slugger until I got my first training bra, and then he just stopped playing catch with me. I wasn’t Slugger anymore. Your mother’s here!

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: If you want to have intercourse with that girl, find out what kind of cologne her father wore.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Good to see you, Mother.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Next time we go to kick someone’s ass, we take the train.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I always prefer the train.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: For the record, I should let you know this is my first time driving an actual motor vehicle.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: You have your learner’s permit, right?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yes, and I have logged a considerable number of hours on a simulator.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Good.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Didn’t work out well.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: All right, can we please go?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: One moment. According to my driver’s ed book, a side mirror is properly adjusted when a portion of the is driver’s door handle is visible in the lower right corner. There’s the handle. Oh, no, too far, bringing it back. Optimized. Now, where is the switch to adjust the passenger side mirror?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: It’s right there.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Where is the passenger side mirror?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: In a parking lot in Hollywood. Now, can we please go?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yes. As soon as I adjust my seat. Whee! Oh, dear. I’m going to have to start again.

turns.transcript: Howard…

turns.speaker: genitals)

turns.speaker: (arriving)
turns.transcript: Hey, Cooper. Wead your wetwaction e-mail. Way to destroy your weputation.

turns.transcript: You see? People have been pointing and laughing at me all morning.

turns.transcript: All right, I’ve had enough. Attention, everyone. I’ m Dr. Sheldon Cooper. As many of you in the physics department might know, my career trajectory has taken a minor detour.

turns.speaker: Kripke
turns.transcript: Off a cwiff.

turns.transcript: My credibility may have been damaged…

turns.speaker: Kripke
turns.transcript: Compwetely wecked.

turns.transcript: He’s eating. That’s a good sign.

turns.transcript: You’re gonna have to wait one hour until you can go swimming again.

turns.transcript: He’s pretty cute.

turns.transcript: Poor judgement, obviously.

turns.speaker: Bernadette

turns.transcript: You talk to Howard lately?

turns.transcript: She seems nice.

turns.transcript: All I said was she seems nice.

turns.transcript: Yeah, well, I love her.

turns.transcript: Look at this stamp. On what authority are they permitted to mutilate patrons as they enter?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: I’m sure it’ll wash off.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Little comfort tonight. I look like a Hell’s Angel.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: There’s Zack.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Are you sure this is what you want to do?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: It’s not what I want to do, it’s what I have to do.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Go, Amy Farrah Fowler. Follow your endocrine system.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Thank you, Sheldon. You’re a good friend.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Please don’t drag this out. This is never going to come off.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Excuse me? Zack? I am Amy Farrah Fowler. We met the other night. I have spent my life in pursuit of pure knowledge. Until I met you, my decisions were founded in logic and reason. And yet here I stand before you, 130 pounds of raging estrogen, longing to grab hold of your gluteus maximus and make Shakespeare’s metaphorical beast with two backs.

turns.transcript: My gluteus what?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: On the other hand, as I look at the blank, ape-like expression on your face, I have decided to adopt the Vulcan practice of Kolinar. Good-bye, Zack.

turns.transcript: Oh, let me do it, Howard.

turns.transcript: Oh, how nice. I loved Finding Nemo.

turns.speaker: Raj

turns.speaker: Josh
turns.transcript: No.

turns.transcript: A kidney, cornea, piece of his liver?

turns.transcript: No.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Would you rather I offer my personal insight?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I don’t need any insights. I just want to know why Penny’s more interested in Stuart than me. We’re practically the same guy.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, I disagree. Stuart is taller, artistic, self-employed and, most significantly, he gets 45 percent off comic books.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You’re right, I really should be asking strangers on the Internet.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: My original point.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: So do you know what kind of research you’ll be doing at this pharmaceutical company?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Well, there are a couple of opportunities available, but I volunteered for the premature ejaculation project. I mean, it’s not like either one of us has heart disease. Oh, I almost forgot. I got you a little present.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Oh, Bernie, no. You didn’t have to.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I wanted to. Come on, open it.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: You bought me a Rolex? How much did this cost?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Oh, you let me worry about the money. I just want my baby to have pretty things.

scene: The apartment. Leonard is dressed smartly and placing wine on the table. Sheldon enters.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Great news. My mom sent me my old Nintendo 64.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Terrific.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You know what this means, don’t you? Break out the Red Bull, it’s time to rock Mario old school.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I kind of have other plans tonight.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: But it’s Friday. Friday’s always vintage game night. Look, mom included the memory card, we can pick up where I left off in 1999 when I had pernicious anaemia.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Well, the thing is, someone’s coming over.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well then, no problem, I have three controllers, the more the merrier.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Sheldon, it’s a date, I have a date coming over.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, well you can’t blame me for not jumping to that conclusion.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Why, what’s so unusual about me having a date?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, statistically speaking…

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Alright, alright. Well, uh, nevertheless, I have one now and I would appreciate it if you would, you know, make yourself scarce.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Leonard, I am a published theoretical physicist with two doctorates and an IQ which can’t be accurately measured by normal tests, how much scarcer could I be?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You know what I mean, could you just give us a little privacy?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You want me to leave the apartment?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yes.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You mean just go someplace else and be… someplace else?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yes.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, why should I leave, this is my apartment too.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I know it is, and if science ever discovers a second member of your species and you two would like some privacy I would be more than happy to get out of your way.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well alright then.

scene: Amy’s lab. She is dissecting a brain.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: I know how you feel. I got a knife slicing through my frontal lobe, too.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Hi.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: What do you want? Do you want me to give the friendship bracelet back?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I never gave you a friendship bracelet.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: When we first met, I made one and pretended you gave it to me. You can have it back if you want.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: No, you made that for you, I want you to have it.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: We know you’re upset, and you have every right to be, but if it’s okay with you, we’d like a second chance to make things right.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: We are really sorry, and we were trying to think of some way to show you how much we care about you.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Which is why it would mean so much if you would agree to be the maid of honour at my wedding.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: What? Wait, is this some kind of practical joke? Like in Norway, when my friends trapped me in a sauna with a horny otter?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: No. I, I want you to be the maid of honour.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Oh, my gosh. No one’s every asked me to be the maid of honour before. Well, that’s not true. Once, but then they all died.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: So is that a yes?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Yes. Yes. Oh, my gosh, I, I have so much to do. There’s the bridal shower and the bachelorette party. What should we do for the bachelorette party? Oh, I know, we’ll go to a Native American sweat lodge, we’ll take peyote, roll around in the mud, and paint fertility symbols on Bernadette’s naked body. So that’s happening.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah, sure, sure. Vegas is fun, too.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: I feel like crying. Of course, I could just be hormonal. Oh, wait. Maybe our menses are finally syncing up. Bernadette? No? Penny?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Sorry.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Really?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, yeah.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Yay!

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Angry Amy.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: What?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’ve been thinking about what happened, and I hope this gift will make things better.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Star Trek DVDs? Why would I want this?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: First of all, you’re welcome. And furthermore, not being familiar with Wil Wheaton’s body of work, there was no way for you to know you were being rude to a national treasure. Get ready for 130 hours of I told you so. (She hands him back the DVDs and slams the door) Fine. I’ll just tell you what happens. Episode one, Encounter at Farpoint. Fade in. The new Enterprise heads out on its maiden voyage to contact the Bandi people of Deneb IV. Enter Wesley Crusher, played by my buddy… (Amy opens door, grabs DVDs, slams door again) She’s hooked.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: So, we’re about to shoot this scene in the movie where the killer ape DNA is slowly taking over my body.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Okay.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: But I realize they’re gluing fur everywhere except my cleavage. So, I asked the director why and he says, it’s important to the story that my boobs be the last things to turn ape.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: It’s sweet that he thinks there’s a story.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, and there’s not even a bathroom on set. I have to go to the gas station across the street. I mean, I was dressed like half an ape and still not even close to the most disgusting person in there.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Leonard, I could use your assistance.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Sure. What’s up?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, now that I’ve given up string theory, I’m struggling to find my next area of focus. So, in your professional opinion, which of these areas do you think is the most promising?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Huh, well, I think there’s some really innovative stuff going on in dark matter.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: That’s helpful. Okay. Of these four areas…

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Sheldon, what did we say about being a nicer friend?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Thank you.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Leonard, what did we say about being a gullible weenie?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It is just so frustrating.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: ‘Cause you’re trying too hard. You need to do something else, get your mind off it.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Hey. How about we bring back Anything Can Happen Thursdays?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Hey, that’s good. Why’d you guys stop doing that?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You made fun of us. Said it was stupid.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah. Sounds like me. Come on, Sheldon. What do you say?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: All right. I officially reinstate Anything Can Happen Thursday.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Great, what do you want to do?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I don’t know. What do you want to do?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I don’t know. What do you want to do?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I’m starting to remember the problem with Anything Can Happen Thursdays.

scene: The living room. Leonard enters carrying a light sabre.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Sheldon? Hello?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Oh, I see you’re reading Saga.

turns.speaker: Girl
turns.transcript: Yeah, I hear it’s pretty good.

turns.transcript: I’ll take your word for it.

turns.transcript: Hi.

turns.transcript: Well, astrophysicist.

turns.speaker: Claire
turns.transcript: That’s perfect. Do you think I could pick your brain for my movie some time? It’s animated sci-fi for kids.

turns.transcript: Sure. I love animated movies.

turns.speaker: Raj

turns.transcript: See ya.

turns.transcript: So?

turns.speaker: Raj

turns.transcript: Star Wars audition, take one, starring Howard Joel Wolowitz, real-life astronaut. Vader is here, now, on this moon. I felt his presence. He’s come for me. He can feel when I’m near…

turns.transcript: I’m in the middle of something.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: So am I.

turns.speaker: (repeatedly)
turns.transcript: Refresh… Refresh… Refresh…

turns.transcript: To be cool? Yeah.

turns.transcript: I did it, I did it, I’m in the queue.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yay! And they say firefighters are the real heroes.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Uh, what number in line are you?

turns.transcript: Uh, fifteen…

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Great.

turns.transcript: …thousand two hundred and eleven.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Damn.

turns.transcript: Oh, they only have Thursday and Sunday passes left.

turns.transcript: Really?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, Thursday’s gone. Just Sunday left.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, Sunday’s the worst. Everybody’s leaving, most of the good panels are over, and the only T-shirts they have left are small and XXXXL.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Sunday’s gone.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Not Sunday, I love Sunday.

turns.speaker: Raj

turns.transcript: Yeah.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I can’t believe we’re not going.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It’s okay. You know, there, there’s always WonderCon in Anaheim, you know? That, that’s just as good. Excuse me.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, guys, this is really sad. And in a different way than it was twenty minutes ago.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I can’t believe we wasted all that time on our Hulk costumes.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: What? You were all going as the Hulk?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Not the same Hulk. Ferrigno, Bana, Norton and Ruffalo.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: We would have been the angry green belles of the masquerade ball.

turns.speaker: All
turns.transcript: Yeah.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: And we’re back to the first kind of sad.

turns.speaker: door)
turns.transcript: Oh hey Penny, wow, look at you, all ready for your showcase, you look great.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Thanks. I just wanted to come by and wish you guys luck with your symposium.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, well, thankyou.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: You know, I got to tell you, a lot of friends would let their friend go alone, but that’s not who you are, you are the kind of guy who stands by a friend when… when he has a symposium to go to.

turns.transcript: I don’t know what to say.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: It’s okay, Leonard (hugs him.)

turns.transcript: Oh, okay, alright, good.

turns.speaker: (arriving)

turns.speaker: Penny

turns.transcript: Uh-huh!

turns.transcript: Well, uh, Penny is on her way to perform in a one night showcase production of Rent, which we are unable to attend because we are going to a symposium on molecular positronium, given by Dr Emile Farminfarmian.

turns.transcript: Howard, wait. Sheldon, I think we should tell them.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Okay, sure. I don’t see a problem with that.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: There’s no symposium, Leonard lied to me, isn’t that right Leonard.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Well… I don’t know what to say.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: It’s okay, I do, look, Leonard is helping Sheldon through a family crisis, he made up the whole story about the symposium with Dr Farmin..farm…ian

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Good for you.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Hah, yeah! Because he didn’t want Sheldon to be embarrassed, and there is nothing to be embarrassed okay, every family in America has a relative holed up in a garage somewhere huffing paint thinner.

turns.speaker: ear)
turns.transcript: No, I’m lost too, I think she skipped a step.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: No, look, Sheldon’s cousin Leo escaped rehab, and he’s in a Motel 8 at Long Beach, the whole family’s going out for an intervention. Leonard is driving Sheldon down there to help him through this because he’s such a good man.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, another hug, thank you.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Alright you guys, good luck.

turns.transcript: Thanks Penny.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Yeah, uh, break a leg.

turns.transcript: Break a leg. (She leaves)

turns.transcript: So, road trip to Long Beach.

turns.transcript: No, we’re not going to Long Beach.

turns.transcript: Why not?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Because Sheldon doesn’t have a drug addicted cousin Leopold.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Oh, too bad. I’ve always wanted to go to Long Beach.

turns.transcript: It’s a very nice community. The Queen Mary is docked there, once the largest ocean liner in the world, it’s now a hotel and restaurant where they host a surprisingly gripping murder mystery dinner.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Sounds fun.

turns.transcript: I’m game.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Shotgun.

turns.transcript: No, no, no, Leonard gets nauseous unless he sits in front, and even then it’s iffy.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Wait, are we really going to Long Beach?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh. Remember when we got this at Comic-Con?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, yeah. The Mr. Spock cuckoo clock.

turns.speaker: Clock
turns.transcript: Live long and prosper. Live long and prosper. Live long and prosper. Live long and prosper.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It’s one of a kind.

turns.transcript: So if it breaks there’d be none of it?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, Leonard, you know, who should keep this? On the one hand, I love Mr. Spock more than you do. On the other hand, I care more about clocks than you do.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: So you think you should keep it?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’ll be right across the hall. You’ll probably be able to hear it.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Keep the clock, Sheldon.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Thank you.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Thank you.

turns.transcript: Thank you?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, now, what about our 3-D chess set?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Let me guess, you want it.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, no, I just didn’t think you’d want a physical reminder of a game you never managed to win. As a kindness, I should probably take all the games.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You know what, Sheldon, take it. In fact, you can have everything, I really don’t care.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Are you sure? These items represent our shared times together.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Well, now they’re yours.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Leonard.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Well, you know what’s gonna happen, he’s just gonna come up with some reason why everything should be his.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: For a man so good at predicting my moves, how come you stink at 3-D chess?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Sheldon, you’re, you’re being a little selfish. Why don’t you let Leonard keep a few things?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It’s not my fault I’m bad at sharing, I skipped kindergarten.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You know what? There is one thing I would like.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yeah, take whatever you want.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I would like to keep the official flag of our apartment.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: But you don’t even like flags.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yeah, I like this one.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: But I designed it.

turns.transcript: But you don’t even understand its symbolism.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, I do. The, the field of blue represents you being miserable, and the lion sticking its tongue out means I’m happy about it.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Come along, Amy. I know when I’m not wanted.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: I don’t think you do, but all right.

turns.transcript: Well, you know how you’re always saying that Amy is a girl who’s your friend, and not your girlfriend?

turns.transcript: Uh-huh.

turns.transcript: You can’t say that anymore.

turns.transcript: Wait. What?

turns.transcript: Me? Well, how am I supposed to fix it?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Simple! You want a girlfriend, Amy wants to be someone’s girlfriend. Take her off my hands. I give you my blessing.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: That is insane.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You’re right. It would never work. Amy finds you tedious.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Okay, good luck.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Wait! What am I supposed to do?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Well, have you considered telling her how you feel?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Leonard, I’m a physicist, not a hippie.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: All right, well, let me see if I can explain your situation using physics. What would you be if you were attached to another object by an inclined plane wrapped helically around an axis?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Screwed.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: There you go.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Amy’s right. He is tedious.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: So, Beverly, did you know Penny is the number three sales rep at our pharmaceutical company?

turns.speaker: Beverly
turns.transcript: Oh, I didn’t realize you two work together.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Well, we don’t exactly. I’m a microbiologist for the research team.

turns.speaker: Beverly
turns.transcript: Oh, what are you currently developing?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Some exciting new anti-anxiety drugs.

turns.speaker: Beverly
turns.transcript: That’s interesting. I just attended a lecture on pediatric anxiety.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Oh, was it, uh, Dr. Jenofski? I just saw his TED Talk.

turns.speaker: Beverly
turns.transcript: It was.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Well, let’s get back to Penny. Hey, weren’t you telling me something great about your company car?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Um, it has seat warmers.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Come in.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Hello, everyone. Oh, Beverly, good to see you. I’d love to chat, but there’s a line that could start moving any minute, so let’s do this. Amy? A proper apology requires three steps. Step one, an admission of wrongdoing. Amy, I was wrong. Step two, a promise never to repeat said action. Amy, that action will never be repeated, and that’s a promise. Step three, an earnest request for forgiveness. Amy, I hope you can forgive me. And I hope you do it right now, ’cause there’s an Uber waiting downstairs, and I don’t want to repeat this apology nonsense with my driver Ganesh.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Fine.

turns.transcript: I’d make fun of Sheldon for having girl problems if I wasn’t in shock that Sheldon has girl problems.

turns.transcript: That’s what your father used to say?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, I took out the bad words and the yeehaw, but you get the gist.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Look, if you don’t want to go to the party, just don’t go. You’re a grown man. Act like one. Tell Amy you want to spend the weekend having a sleepover and playing video games with your friends. Maybe she’ll dig it. Women like a firm hand on the tiller.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I can never find the tiller. I got a book; it didn’t help.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yeah, I always thought if I were ever enslaved, it would be by an advanced species from another planet, not some hotsy-totsy from Glendale.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Now, I downloaded an app that might be helpful in this situation. (Phone makes whip sound)

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You’re right. I’m smart as a whip. I should be able to figure this out.

turns.speaker: Zombie
turns.transcript: Brains!

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Keep it down, we’re working here.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Okay, we’ve got the cipher decoded.

turns.speaker: Emily
turns.transcript: How’s it going with the globe?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: We used the coordinates to locate the cities.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I’m putting the city names in the grid now. I’m sure that’ll give us the code to the safe.

turns.speaker: Zombie
turns.transcript: Solve puzzle too fast! Slow down!

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yup. Got the code.

turns.speaker: Zombie
turns.transcript: Just saying, no refund for finish early!

scene: The apartment. Sheldon goes to sit in his spot.

turns.transcript: Sorry, somebody’s sitting there.

turns.transcript: Who?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: My Physics Bowl Trophy!

turns.transcript: I know someone who would disagree.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Who?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: My Physics Bowl Trophy! (In weird voice) “Leonard is so smart, Sheldon who?”

turns.transcript: Alright that is very immature.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You’re right, I’m sorry. (In voice, waving trophy in Sheldon’s face) I’m not!

turns.speaker: (entering)
turns.transcript: Okay, new contest.

turns.transcript: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I’m settling once and for all who is the smartest around here. Okay, are you ready?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Absolutely.

turns.transcript: Bring it on.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay. Marsha, Jan and Cindy were the three daughters of what TV family? (They stare at her.) The Brady Bunch. Okay, Sammy Hagar replaced David Lee Roth as the lead singer in what group?

turns.transcript: No.

turns.speaker: Penny

turns.transcript: What?

turns.transcript: They always say the children aren’t to blame, but, come on.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I’m not joking, Howie. You heard what he said about his parents. It was the little things they kept bottled up. I don’t want that to happen to us.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: How can I convince you it won’t?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: And here I am in the trap. You just keep talking. I’m gonna chew my leg off.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Just tell me one thing that bothers you, and I promise I won’t get mad.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Okay. The truth is, sometimes, you’re too beautiful.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Oh. Howie, be serious.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Okay, okay. I really don’t like how your wings poke me when we sleep ’cause you’re an angel.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Okay, fine, maybe it was a bad idea.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I just don’t think the secret to a happy marriage is going out of our way to criticize each other. Although, there are ways to improve our communication. One thing I learned when I was in couples therapy was…

turns.transcript: Who were you in couples therapy with?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Not important.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Was it your mom?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Not important.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: It was your mom.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Anyway, the therapist had us tell each other what we loved about one another.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Oh, that’s so sweet. I want to do that.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: All right.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Okay, um, I love that you make me laugh.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Thank you. And I love that you’re strong and independent.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: And yet, I still love when you hold a door for me.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I love that I’m kind of a slob around here, and you’re okay with that.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Uh-huh. And I love that I work and do all the cleaning, and you’re okay with that.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: See, I am. Isn’t this great?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: How much will it hurt?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: It’s just a tiny skin sample. You saw me do it to myself.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: On a scale of one to ten, where one is a pebble in your shoe and ten is the monkey you thought was your pet biting your face off.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: A two.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Eating a whole Altoid?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Sheldon, if I’m gonna synthesize a neural network from our skin cells, I need to harvest them. Now, I’ve done this dozens of times, but if you’re too scared you don’t have to.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: No, this is for science. I can be brave for science.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Thank you.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, jiminy, that’s cold.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Just think how happy you’ll be in a few weeks when I’ve converted our skin cells into functional brain cells.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: All right, just warn me before you do it.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Okay. Three, two, and we’re done.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You tricked me. You didn’t say one.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: It didn’t hurt, did it?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: No, but three, two and we’re done is incomplete. You know those things bother me. It’s like hearing da-da-da-da-da-dah without yelling…

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Okay, fine, one.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Thank you. Now yell charge and we can get out of here.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Are you sure you want us here when you meet this woman?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Oh yes. In my culture it’s expected to have a chaparone to oversee a first date. Plus I want to make a good impression and, no offence, but with you guys here I look like six two.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: The nuns always chaparoned the dances at my high school. They used to make us leave room between us for the holy spirit.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Hindus do the same thing. Except they leave room for a cow.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Listen, I love your charming racist humour, but any chance you could not knock my religion while she’s here.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Yesterday you made fun of me for eating lox.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: It’s different. You’re people don’t worship lox.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Well clearly you’ve never been to brunch with my cousins.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: So, arranged marriages. The parents just decide, and then you have to get married?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Oh, no, no, I get a say in it. But I’m sure whoever shows up will be better company than a threesome I’ve been having with Aunt Jemima and Mrs Butterworth.

turns.speaker: Girl
turns.transcript: Excuse me, are you Rajesh?

turns.speaker: Raj
