turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Remember, seven o’clock.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Got it.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Pacific Daylight time!

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Bite me!

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Please reserve that butch spirit for the lanes.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Your scan data will be very elpful to my research. You have a remarkable brain.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I know. Although I’ve always hated how my right frontal lobe looks in pictures.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Common complaint among men. Nothing’s ever big enough, except when they get a tumour. Then you never hear the end of it.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’d love to see a scan of your brain sometime.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Oh, I’ll send you a link, but its physiology is fairly unimpressive.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, I can’t believe that.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Your unwillingness to accept empirical evidence suggests an attempt at flattery.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: My apologies. I’ve been living with your son too long. Gotten into some bad habits.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Understandable.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Can I make you a cup of tea?

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: I doubt it, but if anyone has a chance, it’s probably you.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I feel very comfortable around you.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: I feel very comfortable around you, too.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It’s surprising because I generally don’t feel comfortable around, well, anyone.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Nor I.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: What are the odds that two individuals as unique as ourselves would be connected by someone as comparatively workaday as your son?

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Is that a rhetorical point or would you like to do the math?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’d like to do the math.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: I’d like that, too.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: (Knock, knock, knock) Penny, (knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Long pause, knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Penny opens door. A dishevelled Sheldon is holding up one hot dog.) Here. I had to trade the others for my life.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: And good evening to you, Siam Palace. This is Sheldon Cooper. Yeah, I’m going to be dining alone this evening, so I’ll be reducing my usual order. I’d like to start with one quarter of the assorted appetizers plate and, uh, one half of the golden treasure for two. Oh, for heaven’s sake, in the mid-18th century, King Rama IV of Siam divided a huge empire amongst the colonial powers of Europe in order to preserve his throne. Surely, you, his cultural descendant, can handle pad thai and dumplings.

turns.speaker: off)
turns.transcript: Sheldon help!

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I need to go, but you keep in mind that my sharply worded comments on yelp.com recently took down a local muffin store. (At Penny’s door, knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny..

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Come in! Hurry!

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Penny?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I’m back here.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: (At Penny’s bedroom door, knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny..

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, for god’s sakes, I’m in the bathroom!

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Shall I come back at a better time?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Get in here! Hurry! Don’t you dare knock.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Hello.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I slipped in the shower, and I think I dislocated my shoulder.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Not surprising. You have no safety mat or adhesive stickers to allow for purchase on a surface with a low coefficient of static friction.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: What?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Tubs are slippery.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I know. I slipped.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I have a series of whimsical duck stickers on the bottom of my tub.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah, okay, whatever. Will you just turn the water off and help me up?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: They’re holding umbrellas.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: What?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: The ducks in my tub.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: They’re whimsical because ducks have neither the need for, nor the ability to use umbrellas.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, my god. I got to go to the emergency room.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, assuming you’re correct that your right humerus is no longer seated in the glenoid socket, I would certainly think so.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, can you drive me?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I don’t drive.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Well, I can’t drive!

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, it seems we’ve reached an impasse.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Ow.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: But I could call you a cab or an ambulance.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: No, no, no, I can’t wait that long, you got to help me, please.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: All right. Let it never be said that Sheldon Lee Cooper ignored the pleas of a damsel in distress.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: No one’s saying that. Let’s go.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, it does seem rather ironic that for want of 99-cent adhesive ducks, we both might die in a fiery car crash.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Do you think there comes a point in life when it stops feeling bad to be left out of things?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Probably not. It’s an evolutionary advantage to be included in group activities.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You know what? I used to be a fan of evolution, but I’ve since evolved, and now I think it’s dumb.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Being left out is a terrible feeling. No one understands that better than I do.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Hey, look at that. Even in your example, you’re all by yourself.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: When there was a lice epidemic at my school, everybody got it except me. I tried to fool everyone by sprinkling sugar in my hair, but I just got attacked by bees.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I can just picture them all right now at Feynman’s house, probably discussing Schrodinger and at the same time, not discussing Schrodinger. See? They’re missing out on hilarious jokes like that.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: And at the same time, not.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It reminds me of when my stupid brother and sister would build forts in the living room and wouldn’t let me in. I hated that so much.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: You know, there’s nothing I can do about getting you invited to the symposium, but if you wanted, we could build a fort.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Isn’t that a little juvenile?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: More juvenile than this?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’ll get the blankets. You Google how to have childlike fun.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I think we’re fitting in quite nicely.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: It’d help if you weren’t drinking light beer.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Oh, what’s so gothic about vodka and cranberry juice?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Hello, it looks like blood. Did you even read the Wiki How link I sent you on being goth?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: No, I’m behind on my wiki-reading I’m kind of on a John Grisham kick right now.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: What?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Well, I finished reading The Pelican Brief and loved it so much, I dived right into The Client. He was a lawyer himself so his novels are accurate as well as entertaining.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Just remember we are lost boys, children of the night.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Great. Lost boys, children of the night. Got it. Can you pass the Chex mix, please. Thank you. We are lost boys.

turns.speaker: Girl
turns.transcript: Good for you.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I’m actually much morelost than he is.

turns.speaker: Girl
turns.transcript: Nice ink.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Thanks. Can we buy you ladies a drink?

turns.speaker: Girl
turns.transcript: Two light beers.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Light beers? Well, Wiki-how about that?

turns.speaker: girl
turns.transcript: What’s your names?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I’m Howard.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Raj.

turns.speaker: Girl
turns.transcript: I’m Bethany.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Nice to meet you, Bethany.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Yes, very nice.

turns.speaker: Bethany
turns.transcript: Nice to meet you too.

turns.speaker: girl
turns.transcript: I’m Sarah. Not that anyone cares.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Do either of you ladies enjoy the novels of John Grisham?

scene: Dr Gablehauser’s office. Sheldon and Leslie are standing across the desk.

turns.speaker: Gablehauser
turns.transcript: People, I am very busy today.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I realise that Dr Gablehauser but it is your job, as head of the department, to mediate all inter-departmental disputes. University policy manual chapter four, subsection two, mediation of inter-departmental disputes.

turns.speaker: Gablehauser
turns.transcript: Fine. Dr Winkle, what colourful name did you call Dr Cooper this time?

turns.speaker: Leslie
turns.transcript: Dr Dumbass.

turns.speaker: Gablehauser
turns.transcript: Dr Cooper, Dr Winkle apologises.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: No she doesn’t.

turns.speaker: Leslie
turns.transcript: No I don’t.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Here’s the problem. I was clearly signed up to use the mainframe in Buckman 204, and Dr Winkle just wantonly ripped the sign-up sheet off the wall.

turns.speaker: Leslie
turns.transcript: It wasn’t even an official sign-up sheet. He printed it himself and he put his name down in every slot for the next six months.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: If it is a crime to ensure that the universities resources are not being squandered chasing sub-atomic wild geese then I plead guilty. (His phone rings.) Oh, Penny!

turns.speaker: Gablehauser
turns.transcript: You need to get that Dr Cooper?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: God, no.

turns.speaker: Leslie
turns.transcript: Well don’t turn it off, you might miss your call from the Nobel committee letting you know you’ve been nominated as dumbass laureate of the year.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh yeah, well, you wouldn’t even be nominated. Dr Gablehauser, I have a series of important multi-bit calculations and simulations to run. All she’s doing is reducing irrelevant data and making a mock…

turns.speaker: rings)
turns.transcript: Excuse me. Gablehauser. (Holding phone out to Sheldon) It’s for you.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Hello. Penny, this is not a good time. No, I told you, you’re not prepared for the Sanctum of Burning Souls. You need to be in a group of at least five for that quest, and one should be a level 35 healer. Penny, I can’t log on and help you. We’ll talk when I get home. (Puts phone down) I’m not getting the computing time, am I?

turns.speaker: Leslie
turns.transcript: Dumbass.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Hey.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, good, you’re home. I need you to do me a favour.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Sure.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Go apologize to Penny.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: What?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Right now would be good.

turns.speaker: (knocking)
turns.transcript: Leonard!

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Although, a few minutes ago would have been better.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I hear you don’t like my stuffed animals, my driving or my punctuality.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: What? Who would tell you something like that? Why would you tell her something like that?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: It doesn’t matter why he told me. It’s true, isn’t it?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Okay, yeah, it’s true, but I can live with that stuff. What I can’t live with is you casually informing me that some guy’s going to be staying in your apartment without even asking me first!

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: That isn’t even your problem, the problem is you don’t trust me!

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, come on. Sheldon, have you ever once heard me say that I don’t trust Penny? Sheldon? Where did he go?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, your yelling must have freaked him out again.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Where are you going? You just walk away in the middle of an argument?!

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: No, I’m going to go find your damn roommate before he hurts himself trying to cross the street or something!

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Why didn’t you say so?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, now I need your permission for that, too?!

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Well, I can’t read your mind, Penny!

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Really? Why not? You’re so smart, and I’m so dumb!

turns.speaker: Emily
turns.transcript: You’re seriously breaking up with me?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Yeah.

turns.speaker: Emily
turns.transcript: And you thought right before Valentine’s Day was a good time to do it?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: You’re right, let’s talk again in a few days.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: My new computer came with Windows 7. Windows 7 is much more user-friendly than Windows Vista. I don’t like that.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Don’t you think looking for a new city to live in is a bit of an overreaction?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Our apartment was broken into, our security system tried to kill me, and as a result, I’m leaving Pasadena forever. Tell me how that’s overreacting.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Come on, Sheldon, you can’t move. Don’t you need to stay in one place so the mother ship can find you when it returns?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, if that were only true. Unfortunately, as I’m earthbound for the foreseeable future, I need to find a location that’s more hospitable than the mean streets of Pasadena. Like Enid, Oklahoma. Low crime rate and high-speed Internet connectivity, but no model train shops. Sorry, Enid.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Is he quitting his job at the university?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, no, he’s going to telecommute. Everybody’s really excited about it.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: All right. Boone, North Carolina. Every summer since 1952, Boone has hosted an outdoor amphitheater portrayal of the life and times of its namesake, Dan’l Boone. Sounds like something that would attract the wrong crowd. Penny, you’re from Nebraska, correct?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Born and raised. (Sheldon crosses Nebraska off his map)

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: How’s Sheldon doing with Amy gone?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Well, the last three nights I’ve had to take him to get a haircut, to the train store, and to a Walgreens in Arcadia where they still have the good ibuprofen. Now ask me how I’m doing with Amy gone.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: How are you doing with…

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Shut up.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: If you’d like, we can help you out.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, that would be great.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I mean, not me, I’ve got a wife and child, but this one posts video of himself flossing on Instagram.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: It was a tutorial. And yes, I’m happy to keep Sheldon company.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Great. Tonight he wants to look at ladders at Home Depot.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Oh, why does he need a ladder?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: He doesn’t; he just likes looking at them. Bring a book.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Gentlemen. You may remember Dr. Nowitzki, She’s back at Caltech for her postdoc.

turns.speaker: Nowitzki
turns.transcript: Hello.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Hello.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Hi. Oh, let me bring a chair for you.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, thanks. Dr. Nowitzki’s going to tell me about the work she did at CERN. And she brought me this duty-free Toblerone.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh. I love those.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Let’s sit somewhere else.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: What just happened?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: A stranger just lured Sheldon away with a candy bar.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Wait, isn’t she the grad student that used to follow him around?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Oh, yeah. Back before he hit puberty and grew man parts.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: So what do you guys think that’s about?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Knowing Sheldon, nothing.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: So, tell me about your scalar dark energy experiment.

turns.speaker: Ramona
turns.transcript: Not ’til you tell me about your latest paper on quantum loop theory.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh. You must be one of those dessert before dinner people.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: He just made her laugh, something’s wrong.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Do you see the way she’s looking at him?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Yeah. Like Bernadette used to look at me.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I keep telling you, close the bathroom door.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Ah, did you see that? She just touched his hand and he didn’t swat it away. What is happening?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Okay, the simplest explanation is usually the right one.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Which is?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: That ain’t Sheldon.

scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon is restless. He gets up and checks the door is locked. He then moves his chest of drawers in front of the door. Goes back to bed.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I do not have to urinate. I am the master of my own bladder. Drat.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Where’s Stuart?

turns.speaker: (sniggering)
turns.transcript: Out.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Who are you?

turns.speaker: Guy
turns.transcript: I’m Dale. He left me in charge.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Really?

turns.speaker: Dale
turns.transcript: Yeah. I don’t get it, either.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I want to return this Wild West and Witches Ka’a expansion pack.

turns.speaker: Dale
turns.transcript: Sorry. I don’t do returns. They’re hard.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Sure, sure. Uh, when will Stuart be back?

turns.speaker: Dale
turns.transcript: I don’t know. He went out for coffee. With a girl.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, I guess I was wrong.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You okay?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Am I okay? Leonard, I’m on a lifelong trajectory that includes a Nobel Prize and cities named after me, all four wisdom teeth fit comfortably in my mouth without need of extraction, and my bowel movements run like a German train schedule. Am I okay?

turns.speaker: Dale
turns.transcript: I’m okay, too!

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: You know, with us living together, maybe we could think about having people over.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: We have people over all the time. We have the maintenance people, the pizza delivery man, that UPS driver who feels the need to ask how parts of me are hanging.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: You know what I meant.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: All right, fine. Let’s say that we were to entertain people. What type of gathering did you have in mind? Huh? A meal? Lunch? Brunch? Dinner? Afternoon tea? A formal tea? Hmm? Is it a party? And if so, what kind of party? Is it a cocktail party? A Tupperware party? Ooh, is it a surprise party? Oh, I hope it’s not a West Coast party, ’cause according to the man on the radio, a West Coast party don’t stop.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: I’m sorry I mentioned it.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, don’t be. You get your hopes up, I knock them down. That’s called teamwork.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Can you pass the Parmesan cheese?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Sure. What are you doing?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’m trying to get the hair out of my eyes.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Sheldon, you are one day late for your haircut.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Thank you for captioning my nightmare.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Lookie here, I got my travel orders.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Payload Specialist Howard Wolowitz is requested to report to the NASA Johnson Space Center, Houston, Texas, for astronaut training Monday eight a.m.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Yeah, but it’s from NASA, so it’s oh eight hundred.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: But it says eight a.m.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: You read it as oh eight hundred.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: It doesn’t have an oh in front of it.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: You know what does have an oh in front of it? Oh, my God, I’m an astronaut, and you’re dying of jealousy.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: So, what kind of things are they… (to Sheldon) will you stop that?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I can’t help it, I feel like a teen heartthrob.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: You know, Sheldon, I used to cut my brother’s hair. I could do it for you.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Penny, I know you mean well, offering the skills of the hill folk, but, um, here in town we don’t churn our own butter, we don’t, uh, make dresses out of gunny sacks, and, uh, we sure as shootin’ don’t get our hair cut by bottle-blonde…

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Sheldon, be nice.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’m sorry, it’s the bad boy attitude that comes with this hair.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: You could go to my guy. He’s at Juan-Juan in Beverly Hills. They bring you a cup of tea, they’ll massage your scalp. It’s about two hundred dollars, but sometimes you look in the next chair and you see a superstar like Tony Danza.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Quick question here, have we actually changed the conversation from I’m going

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Now who’s dying of jealousy? Oh, it’s you.

turns.speaker: (voice)
turns.transcript: Howard, get the door!

turns.speaker: (voice)
turns.transcript: Really? Is that what you do when someone knocks? Thank you. I had no idea! (opening door) Hey, buddy. What brings you to my little slice of hell?

turns.speaker: (voice)
turns.transcript: Who is it?!

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: It’s Leonard!

turns.speaker: (voice)
turns.transcript: You’re gonna have to play outside! I’m not dressed to receive!

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: No one cares, Ma! So, what’s up?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Listen, I need to talk to you about something.

turns.speaker: rings)
turns.transcript: Momentito. Yello. Oh, Stephanie, thanks for calling me back. I was worried… Oh… Uh-huh… Uh-huh… Uh-huh… No, I understand… Sure, we can be friends. Absolutely. Thanks for calling. Yeah, you have a nice day, too. (To Leonard) You are dead to me.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Mm-hmm, mm-hmm, yeah, I’m telling you the Match.com chicks are much looser than on eHarmony. You know, I, I gotta call you back. I won a bet, and it’s time to collect.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I don’t know about you, but I feel empowered.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Hey, can I stay here tonight?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Shh-shh-shh-shh. Sheldon’s asleep. What’s going on?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Well, Howard’s a complete and total ass, Bernadette’s in my bed, and no matter how much you stroke Amy’s hair, she bites.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: What?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Never mind. Can I stay here or not?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Uh, sure.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: All right.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: So, how do you wanna do this?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Well, I’m not getting in bed with him.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yeah, it is a little like getting into Dracula’s coffin.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: We’re just gonna have to make the best of this.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Okay, when you say make the best of it.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Sleep.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Right. So we’ll just call the middle here the Neutral Zone.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: The what?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Star Trek. You know, the Neutral Zone between the Federation and the Romulan Empire.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, okay. Just like old times.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Of course, sometimes the Federation and the Romulans would enter the Neutral Zone to negotiate a temporary truce.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Sweetie, let me put this in a way you’ll understand. From the waist down, my shields are up.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Got it, got it. We can do all kinds of stuff from the waist up, you know?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Go to sleep.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Good night.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Please tell me you’re not having coitus.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: We are not having coitus.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Can you guarantee that it won’t happen at any time during the night?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yes.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: No.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Hello, Stuart.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Oh, hey, Sheldon. Can I help you find something today?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: No, no. I was just sitting at home thinking about how it might be nice to catch up with my ninth favourite person.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Ninth?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You moved up one. My pen pal in Somalia was kidnapped by pirates. So, uh, how are you?

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Uh, not so good. My shrink just killed himself and blamed me in the note.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Great. Great. So, what’s new with your family? How’s your mother? Is she alive?

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Yeah.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: And your father? Alive?

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Yes.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: How about your grandparents, they alive?

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: No.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, I’m so sorry for your loss. On a cheerier note, I have a teeth-cleaning appointment this afternoon. What do you say you take me over there, buddy boy?

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: I’m sorry, you want me to take you to the dentist?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yes. And now, I can’t make any promises, but that’s the sort of thing that gets a fella on the short list for the number eight friend slot.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Sheldon, I’m working. I can’t take you to the dentist. Also, and I can’t stress this enough, I don’t want to take you to the dentist.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Can’t help a friend out in a time of need, huh? I see where your therapist was coming from.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Who leaves their bike in the hallway? You know, if I knew how to ride one, I’d steal it.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Ignore him, he’s just cranky because Bert from the geology lab won a big grant.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, I heard him interviewed on the radio. You know, when they told him he won, he didn’t believe it, but then he did believe it. It was so funny.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Who listens to the radio any more?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Bert is studying the way microbes in rocks can survive in extreme environmental conditions.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: They say it could be a potential indicator of life on other planets.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: You know what, I’ve met Bert. Isn’t he an indicator of life on other planets?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You used to make those jokes about me. Now everything is Bert, Bert, Bert.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: You know, Sheldon, maybe if you take the time to actually read Bert’s research, you’d be less bitter about him winning.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You want me to read a geology paper?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Honestly, I just want you to be quiet but I’m all out of taffy.

turns.speaker: phone)
turns.transcript: Hello.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Hey, Claire.

turns.speaker: Claire
turns.transcript: Hey, what’s up?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Hi, yeah. Um, I was wondering, if you’re free Saturday night, all my friends are going to a wine tasting.

turns.speaker: Claire
turns.transcript: Sure, I guess. If you don’t think meeting your friends is too big a step.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Why would it be too big a step?

turns.speaker: Claire
turns.transcript: I don’t know. I just don’t want things to get weird.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Nothing to worry about. People meet people all the time, and it isn’t weird. I met Bon Jovi once, which you’d think might be weird. Turns out, total sweetheart.

turns.speaker: Claire
turns.transcript: Okay, but you and I have been keeping things casual. Uh, will you introduce me as your friend or as your girlfriend? What if I like them and they don’t like me? What if they like me and I don’t like them?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Boy, it wasn’t this hard with Bon Jovi. I said you rock, he said, thanks, man, and that was that.

scene: Mrs Wolowitz’s house. Raj is climbing out of the window.

turns.speaker: (off)
turns.transcript: Where you going?

turns.speaker: (screams)
turns.transcript: No!

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Wooh, I’m all sweaty, anybody want to log on to second life and go swimming, I just built a virtual pool.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: No, I can’t look at you or your avatar right now.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Sounds like your neighbour’s home.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Excuse me.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Don’t forget the mail you took accidentally on purpose so you’d have an excuse to talk to her.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, right, right right right right.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Stealing snail mail, very old school, I like it.

turns.speaker: hallway)
turns.transcript: Penny, the mailman did it again, he… (looks up to see Penny kissing a hunky man) Oh! Sorry.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Um, no, hi Leonard, this is Doug, Doug, this is my neighbour Leonard.

turns.speaker: Doug
turns.transcript: What’s up bro.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Not much. Bro.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Is, is everything okay.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Uh, yeah, uh, I just, I got your mail again, here.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Thank you, I’ve got to talk to that mailman.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh no, that’s probably not such a good idea. Civil servants have a documented propensity to, you know, snap.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, well, thank you, again.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: No problem. Bye. Oh, and, bye, bro! (Returns to apartment).

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Penny for your thoughts.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: What’s the matter.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: No, I’m fine. Penny’s fine, the guy she’s kissing is really fine and…

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Kissing, what kind of kissing? Cheeks? Lips? Chaste? French?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: What is wrong with you?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I’m a romantic.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Please don’t tell me that your hopeless infatuation is devolving into pointless jealousy.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: No, I’m not jealous, I’m just a little concerned for her. I didn’t like the look of the guy that she was with.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Because he looked better than you?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yeah. He was kinda dreamy.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, at least now you can retrieve the black box from the twisted smouldering wreckage that was once your fantasy of dating her, and analyse the data so that you don’t crash into geek mountain again.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I disagree, love is not a sprint, it’s a marathon. A relentless pursuit that only ends when she falls into your arms. Or hits you with the pepper spray.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Well, I’m done with Penny. I’m going to be more realistic and go after someone my own speed.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Like who?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I don’t know. Olivia Geiger?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: The dietician at the cafeteria with the limp and the lazy eye?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yeah.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, I don’t think you have a shot there. I have noticed that Lesley Winkle recently started shaving her legs. Now, given that winter is coming one can only assume that she is signalling sexual availability.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I don’t know, you guys work in the same lab.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: So?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: There are pitfalls, trust me, I know. When it comes to sexual harassment law I’m… a bit of a self-taught expert.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Look, Howard, if I were to ask Lesley Winkle out it would just be for dinner, I’m not going to walk into the lab, ask her to strip naked and dance for me.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Oh, then you’re probably okay.

turns.speaker: Susan
turns.transcript: Penny, I don’t know what I was worried about. You’re friends are just lovely.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, thanks, Mom.

turns.speaker: Susan
turns.transcript: Although that Sheldon is a bit peculiar.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Is he? I never noticed.

turns.speaker: Wyatt
turns.transcript: He reminds me of that turkey we had who drowned looking up at the rain.

turns.speaker: Randall
turns.transcript: Cops, cops, be cool.

scene: Penny’s bathroom. Leonard is vomiting in the toilet.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, sweetie. You really can’t hold your liquor, can you?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I’m okay. Just a little mouthwash, and then I’m gonna rock your world. (Penny vomits in sink) Are you okay? (Vomits in toilet again)

scene: Amy’s apartment. Amy is playing a harp.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Five, six, seven, eight. Tall and tan and young and lovely, the girl from Ipanema goes walking, and when she passes, each one she passes goes…

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Oh… You are aware that your ritualistic knocking behaviour is symptomatic of obsessive compulsive disorder?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Is not. Is not, is not.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Denial. Denial, denial. Come in.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Thank you.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Would you like to hear me play a bossa nova standard on the harp?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: No.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: How about the theme song to the classic television show Diff’rent Strokes? Now the world don’t move to the beat…

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: No.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Well, that’s every song I know. What’s up?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You’re good friends with Penny, right?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Best friends, besties, BFFs, peas in a pod, sisters who would share travelling pants. Go on.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I was hoping she might listen to you about the dangers of owning unhygienic furniture.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: For general educational purposes, or has she acquired a bar stool dipped in cholera?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Cholera is water-borne. You’re mocking me.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Yes, I am.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Penny has dragged a chair in off the street whose unknown provenance jeopardizes the health and welfare of every resident in our building.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Sheldon, just because you have a focus on cleanliness bordering on the psychotic doesn’t mean I have to participate.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: All right, name your price.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Kiss me where I’ve never been kissed before.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You mean like Salt Lake City?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Never mind. I’ll talk to Penny.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Thank you.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Will you listen to me play my harp now?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: No. I dislike the sound of the harp. Its overuse in classic television sitcoms always makes me think I’m going to experience an episode from my past. (Amy plays glissando) I’m sorry, Mommy. Don’t be mad at me. Don’t do that!

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Stuart, you didn’t have to get us a baby gift.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Oh. Just homemade coupons for things you might need help with before the baby gets here. Going to the grocery store, driving you to the doctor, if you’re not in a hurry I can dig you a koi pond.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: A foot massage?

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: And that’s not me being creepy, that’s for either of you.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: This is very nice Stuart, thank you.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: How come this one’s on the back of an eviction notice?

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Oh, yeah. Uh, now that you mention it, can I live here?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Stuart, we’d love to help you out, but this a bad time, we’re about to have a baby.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Or is that why this is a great time? Think about it, when that baby comes you’re gonna need all the help you can get.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Thank you, but I’m not really sure.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Hang on, maybe it’s not the worst idea. I mean, he did do a good job taking care of my mother.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: That woman didn’t get heat rash once with me on powder patrol.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I guess you could stay for a few days and we’ll see how it goes.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Thank you. And it’s only temporary, just till I get back on my feet, or the baby goes off to college, whichever happens first.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: When would you move in?

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Well, uh, my car broke down in your driveway, so I’m gonna say now. But I am ready to be helpful. In fact, I’m gonna go vacuum.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Hmm. Actually I just did that this morning.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Okay, then I’ll dust.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I did that, too.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Then I’ll check the batteries in the smoke detectors.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Howard just did that.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Yeah, let him do it.

scene: The apartment door. Sheldon is on the phone.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, hi mom. No, I told you I’d call you when I got home, I’m not home yet. (Walks through door) Alright, I’m home. The Arctic expedition was a remarkable success, I’m all but certain there’s a Nobel Prize in my future. Actually, I shouldn’t say that. I’m entirely certain. No, mother, I could not feel your church group praying for my safety. The fact that I’m home safe is not proof that it worked, that logic is Post Hoc Ergo Propter Hoc. No, I’m not sassing you in Eskimo talk.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I’m going to go let Penny know we’re back.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Mother, I have to go. Yeah, love you. Bye. (To his spot) Hello, old friend. (Sits) Daddy’s home.

turns.speaker: (off)
turns.transcript: I’m going to need a larger shirt. This one’s a little tight under the arms.

turns.speaker: Assistant
turns.transcript: Okay.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Do you think maybe it’s tight because you’re wearing long underwear?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yes, of course that’s why it’s tight.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: All right, let me rephrase the question. Why are you wearing long underwear?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You’re kidding. Shouldn’t the question be why aren’t you?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: No, it should be: why are you?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Leonard, these rental tuxedos have been worn by hundreds of sweaty strangers. I don’t like my own sweat touching my skin, how do you think I feel about theirs?

turns.speaker: Assistant
turns.transcript: Why don’t you slip this on?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Said the hangman offering a noose.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Well, that wasn’t as entertaining as when he rents bowling shoes, but it was right up there.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Well, that’s it. My orders have been rescinded. I am officially no go to space.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I’m sorry, Howard, but I got to tell you, I’m a little relieved you’re not going.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Why?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Come on, you were gonna go up in a rocket designed in the 1960s by the Russians.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Yeah, so?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: When was the last time you were at Best Buy and you heard someone say, ooh, check out this Blu-ray player, it must be good, it was built in Russia”?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Well, their technology isn’t that bad.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: When you come back to Earth in a Soyuz capsule, you free-fall from space at 500 miles per hour, and the only thing that slows you down is a little parachute that pops out right before you crash into the ground. And the whole thing was designed by the same brilliant minds who were unable to capture Rocky and Bullwinkle.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: All right, well, whatever. I wasn’t worried.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: You weren’t?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Let me explain the difference between you and me. You watch Star Trek. I live it.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Oh, please. I don’t remember the episode of Star Trek where the guy never goes to space and brags about it in a tuxedo store.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Make all the jokes you want, but there’s only one of us here brave enough to almost do what I almost did.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Ah, much better.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You must be burning up.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: A little. But not more than your urethras will be after whatever’s in those pants swims up them. Well, I cut quite the dashing, yet hygienic figure, don’t I? I look like the Flash about to get married. Oh! A tissue! A tissue! Oh, good Lord!

turns.speaker: Assistant
turns.transcript: Uh, where’s he going?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: He keeps emergency Purell in the car.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Keys! Keys! Keys!

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: So, Sheldon, how you doing?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: That’s how you start a psychotherapy session? How am I doing? I was promised a riverboat journey into the jungles of my subconscious. Instead, I get the same question I hear from the lady who slices my bologna at Ralph’s.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I’m sorry, I’ll start again.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Would it be helpful to you if I told you about my dreams?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Um, I don’t know, maybe.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I recently had a dream that I was a giant. But everything around me was to scale, so it all looked normal.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: How did you know you were a giant if everything was to scale?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I was wearing size a million pants.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Why don’t we just talk?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Ah, the talking cure. Classical Freudian, good choice. If it will help speed things along, uh, my answers to the standard Rorschach ink blot test are A, a bat, B, a bat, C, a bat, and D, my father killing my mother with a hypodermic needle.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Why don’t I just start? Sometimes people have trouble accepting accolades if, on a subconscious level, they don’t feel they deserve them. Do you think maybe that’s what’s happening here?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Really, Leonard? You’re just going to try to recycle Adler’s doctrine of the inferiority complex? I could probably get that from the woman at Ralph’s. And she’d let me taste some pieces of cheese for free.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: But it could be part of your problem. Let me give you an example. When I was eight, I won a ribbon at the science fair for my project, “Do Lima Beans Grow Better to Classical Music.” But my mother pointed out that it was just a rehash of my brother’s earlier “Do Lima Beans Grow Worse to Rock ‘n’ Roll.” I felt so guilty, I gave the ribbon back.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: And how did that make you feel?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Terrible. I worked really hard on that project. I stayed up all night singing the clown’s aria from Pagliacci to a lima bean sprout.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Go on.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: It wasn’t my fault. I had never seen my brother’s project. And my mother could’ve told me before instead of at the ceremony in front of everyone.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: So, I hear you saying you’re angry with your mother.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Damn right, I’m angry with my mother. For God’s sake, I was eight years old. She humiliated me. That’s when the bed-wetting started again.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Thank you, Leonard.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: For what?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: If someone as damaged as you can find his way to crawl out of bed each morning, I think I can face a simple award ceremony.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Wait, that’s it? I thought we had a whole hour!

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Guys, our topic is encouraging women in science, can you at least play a less sexist game

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: How is it sexist? My character wields a battle axe as well as any man.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Not to mention she has mammary glands that could nurse a family of 30. And have enough milk left over to open a Baskin Robbins.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Mother, warrior-princess, franchise owner, I hear glass ceilings shattering all over town.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Sheldon, you’re always saying how much smarter you are than me. Spend five seconds and come up with one idea on how to get more women into science.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: All your ideas address the issue at a university level. By then it’s too late. You need to design an outreach program that targets girls at the middle school level and sets them on an academic track towards the hard sciences.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: That’s actually good. Why didn’t I think of that?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Some people are otters, some people are rocks.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I wonder if there’s a way we could give the idea a trial run.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Maybe I could call my old middle school, see if we can talk to some of the female students.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: That’s great, try to set up something for the three of us to go over there.

turns.speaker: Sheldon

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Well, I’m having a good time, too. If you don’t mind me asking, why did you and your wife split up?

turns.speaker: Dave
turns.transcript: Oh, you know how it is, we wanted different things. I wanted children, and she wanted a pastry chef named Jean-Philippe.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Oh, I’m, I’m so sorry.

turns.speaker: Dave
turns.transcript: No, it’s, it’s fine. It’s why I left England. It reminded me too much of her. Cold, gloomy and easily accessed by a Frenchman through a tunnel.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Hey. So, where are they?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Across the street, in the left window.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Right here.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You just happen to have those in the car?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Kinda. Before I met Howie, I liked to keep close tabs on my boyfriends.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: By stalking them?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: No. Stalkers are creepy. I’m just a harmless little girl with military-grade spy equipment.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, there he is.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: He’s cute, right?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Can I see?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: What, now you’re interested? You didn’t even want to come.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I know, but you guys make being a crappy friend look fun.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Fine.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yeah, okay, I see him. It looks like they’re having a nice time. I wish I could hear what they’re saying.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Yeah, I should’ve brought my parabolic microphone.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Your what?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Nothing. Not important.

turns.speaker: Dave
turns.transcript: So you’ve never been married?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: No. I mean, to be completely honest, I’ve, I’ve only been in one long-term relationship.

turns.speaker: Dave
turns.transcript: Oh. What happened with that?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: That’s a good question. After five years, it was just feeling like more work than it should be.

turns.speaker: Dave
turns.transcript: Oh, that’s too bad. Was he a neurobiologist like you?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: No. He’s a theoretical physicist at Caltech.

turns.speaker: Dave
turns.transcript: I love teaching math, but that would be my dream job. What’s his focus?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Um, used to be string theory, now it’s dark matter. But let’s not discuss Sheldon. Let’s get back to you.

turns.speaker: Dave
turns.transcript: Wait, you’re not talking about Dr. Sheldon Cooper?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: I’m trying not to. Do you know him?

turns.speaker: Dave
turns.transcript: No, but I’ve followed his work for years. He’s a rock star. You’ve got to tell me about him. What’s he like?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: He really seems into her.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I took a video. I forgot how much fun this is.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Okay, we saw them. Can we go catch the movie?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Why’d you bring him?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I had to; we’re married now.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Ugh, I hear that.

turns.speaker: Dave
turns.transcript: I’m sorry, just one more question about Sheldon.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Sure, why not?

turns.speaker: Dave
turns.transcript: It’s more of a four-part question, really. When he wrote his paper on supersingular prime numbers, how long did it take?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Um about an hour and half.

turns.speaker: Dave
turns.transcript: Wow. I mean, wow. And you were there to see it?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Yes. Yep. We were on a date. Very much like this one.

turns.speaker: Dave
turns.transcript: Mm. I doubt it was like this one. I mean, he’s a genius, and I wasn’t even smart enough to figure out why my wife always smelled of croissants.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: What was the rest of your question?

turns.speaker: Dave
turns.transcript: Do you think you could introduce me to him?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Really? You-you want me to introduce you to my ex-boyfriend?

turns.speaker: Dave
turns.transcript: You’re right, it’s, it’s weird. No, wait. Do it. No. I changed my mind. I’d be too nervous. Oh, I don’t know what to do.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Are we gonna be much longer? I really have to go to the bathroom.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Right here.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
